items.title: Personal developer portfolio
items.subtitle: A modern, performance-optimized portfolio designed to showcase my projects, experience, and technical background.

sections.title: Challenge
text: The goal was to create a portfolio that goes beyond a static showcase and clearly communicates my technical level, way of thinking, and real-world development experience.
The main challenge was maintaining a clean and simple design while still supporting richer content such as detailed project descriptions, certifications, and multilingual support.

sections.title: Approach
text: The portfolio was designed as a modular React application with a strong focus on reusable components and a clearly separated content structure managed through i18n.
Special attention was given to performance, responsive behavior, accessibility, and a smooth user experience across different devices.

sections.title: Result
text: The result is a scalable and maintainable portfolio that can be easily extended with new projects and content without changes to the core architecture.
The portfolio serves not only as a presentation tool but also as a practical demonstration of my approach to frontend architecture and UX decisions.

items.title: Web racing game
items.subtitle: A 2D browser-based racing game built in pure JavaScript, focused on game logic, collision handling, and movement mathematics.

sections.title: Challenge
text: The goal of the project was to design and implement an interactive web game without using external game libraries or frameworks.
A key challenge was handling game logic, object collisions, smooth animations, and realistic vehicle movement in real time.

sections.title: Approach
text: The game was designed using the MVC (Model–View–Controller) architecture, ensuring a clear separation between game logic, rendering, and user input.
A significant part of the implementation involved calculating vehicle rotation angles using sine and cosine functions, enabling realistic turning and accurate collision detection for rotated objects.
The game world was rendered using HTML canvas along with a custom scene system (menu, gameplay, pause, win, lose).

sections.title: Result
text: The result is a fully functional 2D racing game with multiple difficulty levels, in-game currency collection, and simple power-ups.
The project provided me with a deep understanding of mathematics in games, animations, collision handling, and the architecture of interactive JavaScript applications.

items.title: DeliGo – multi-layer backend system
items.subtitle: A group project focused on designing and implementing a complex backend system simulating a real production environment, including networking, servers, and security.

sections.title: Challenge
text: The goal of the project was not only to implement a working application but also to understand how a real backend system operates within a networked environment.
The challenge was to design an architecture that was clear, extensible, and closely aligned with production-grade solutions used in real companies.

sections.title: System architecture and design
text: The system was designed as a multi-layer application with clearly separated responsibilities between the presentation layer, business logic, and persistence.
The presentation layer exposed REST APIs, handled HTTP requests, and validated input data, while the business logic remained isolated from infrastructure concerns.
The persistence layer was abstracted using interfaces, allowing it to be replaced without impacting the rest of the system.

sections.title: Network, server, and infrastructure
text: An important part of the project was simulating a real network environment where individual components communicated over the network using IP addresses and ports.
I worked on diagnosing service availability issues, proper request routing, and troubleshooting scenarios where services could not reach each other.
The server infrastructure was manually configured and enhanced with a reverse proxy acting as a central entry point and protecting internal services from direct access.

sections.title: Security and extensibility
text: Security was considered from the beginning, including input validation, access restriction to sensitive parts of the system, and minimizing the attack surface.
The use of modular architecture, interfaces, and clear contracts enabled further system expansion without rewriting existing code.
The project helped me transition from solving isolated tasks to thinking systemically about applications as a whole.

items.title: OCR Shop Receipt – desktop application
items.subtitle: A desktop application focused on automated processing of receipts using OCR, AI data extraction, and live camera input.

sections.title: Project goal
text: The goal of the project was not only to recognize text from images but to build a complete receipt-processing workflow—from camera capture and image preprocessing to OCR, AI-based data extraction, normalization, and presentation within the application.
The project aimed to simulate a real-world usable system rather than a one-off script or demo model.

sections.title: Solution architecture
text: The solution was split into an Electron desktop application serving as the GUI layer and a Python backend responsible for all heavy processing logic.
Electron acted as a cross-platform UI, launching Python processes, sending inputs, and receiving structured outputs.
The Python backend was gradually refactored into a modular architecture with separate logic for camera handling, image processing, OCR, and AI extraction.

sections.title: Camera and hardware handling
text: One of the biggest challenges was working with an external camera designed for close-range receipt capture.
Standard manufacturer tools did not support the camera, and automatic focus was unusable for macro capture.

The solution involved manual camera initialization in OpenCV, identifying the device using the Device Instance Path, and experimenting with custom Python scripts for manual focus and camera parameter tuning.

sections.title: Image preprocessing and OCR
text: Before running OCR, image quality had to be addressed due to varying lighting conditions, blur, wrinkled paper, and inconsistent fonts.
Techniques such as grayscale conversion, thresholding, contrast enhancement, and region-of-interest cropping were applied.
The project demonstrated that OCR output quality is highly dependent on input image quality, with most effort spent on preprocessing rather than the OCR model itself.

sections.title: AI data extraction and system challenges
text: The project evolved from basic text recognition to AI-driven extraction of structured data such as store name, date, items, prices, and total amount.
It became clear that OCR alone was insufficient—AI models needed to understand document context and layout.
The project also revealed performance limitations of consumer hardware, including high RAM usage, CPU load, and challenges related to GPU acceleration.

sections.title: Key takeaways
text: The project provided a very realistic insight into the challenges of combining a desktop application, Python backend, and AI models.
It offered hands-on experience with debugging across OS, drivers, libraries, and hardware layers.
Even though the project is not actively developed, it represents valuable experience in designing complex systems outside of traditional web applications.

items.title: Mobile game in Unity
items.subtitle: A simple mobile game built in Unity and C# that represents my first independent IT project and my first experience with game development.

sections.title: Project beginnings
text: This project started as my very first independent IT project, which I began without any prior experience in game development.
Initially, I worked with Blender, experimenting with simple 3D objects and scenes, which eventually led to the idea of creating my own game.

sections.title: Game development in Unity
text: The game was developed in Unity using C#. It was a simple yet fully playable mobile game built on physics-based movement and precise controls.
The player controlled a ball moving left and right via touch input, with the goal of avoiding obstacles and reaching the finish line.

sections.title: Game mechanics and levels
text: The game featured approximately 20 levels with gradually increasing difficulty.
After completing a level, the next one was unlocked, creating a simple but motivating progression system.
The project helped me understand fundamental principles of game logic, collision handling, physics, and game state management.

sections.title: Publishing and experience
text: The game was successfully published on Google Play, where it was publicly available for some time.
Although the game is no longer available on Google Play and the source code has been lost, the project remains a significant milestone for me.
It taught me how to take a project from an initial idea to real-world release and gave me my first practical exposure to software development as a whole.
